column3: The first way the factory would cover up spoiled meat was to put it in sausage. In paragraph one the author writes, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever mear was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." This explains how they would put spoiled meat with fresh meat, instead of throwing the spoiled meat out. If the factory didn't put the spoiled meat in sausage, they would rub it with soda to take away the small, or they would use chemicals to enhance aspects of the meat. From paragraph two it states, "...how the meat that was taken our of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." This explains there use of soda and chemicals to mask the spoiled meat. Next up, the factory would stuff ham with the spoiled meat using a machine and a needle. The text explains in paragraph two, "... a cachine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled..." This evidence further describes how they would mask spoiled meat. Finally, once the factory discovered how to take the bone out of a ham, they would insert a white-hot iron, and they would go on to sell "boneless hams" or "California hams" and fancy "skinned hams" which all were filled with spoiled meat. However no one would buy skinned hams, until they were cooked, and chopped up fine, which they then called "head cheese". Evidence comes from paragraph two, "...but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. The packers were always originating such schemes—they had what they called “boneless hams,” which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and “California hams,” which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy “skinned hams,” which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them—that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled “head cheese!” These lines of text explain the procedure that happened to the hams just for them to be sold. If Europe old sausage came back however, no matter how moldy or white it was, the factoru would dose it with borax and glycerin and then pack it with fresh meat just to sell again.

They used a variety of techniques to disguise the smell or appearance and to mask the unpleasant taste of spoiled meat. They also employed a process of stuffing ham at a specific point in order to hide the spoiled meat within.

Jonas relayed tales about the condition of the cured meats, how sour they often were, and how they were treated with soda to erase the unpleasant aroma.  Although there were instances of spoiled hams found during the process, some with an intense stench that defied sensory endurance, the workers employed a more potent pickle to obliterate the odor.  The meat that was cut into hundred-revolutions per minute was mixed with half a ton of other meat, effectively concealing its original odor.

column3: The structure of acient Egyptian system is.  It is the levels of people that they had in their system to see how important they are. column4: The structure of ancient Egyptian society was built around different ranks of people based on their perceived importance. Those with the highest status, were considered gods, holding the highest position in the hierarchy. In contrast, slaves occupied the lowest rung, while normal workers came next, followed by the military class, and finally, the pharaohs, coming in the second-highest position.  Evidence suggests that the passage describes a gradual process of improvement and degradation within the social pyramid. The passage outlines the actions taken by each hierarchy to achieve higher ranks in the afterlife, reinforcing the belief in karma and subsequent advancement based on one's actions.

column3: Three elements of an ideal tragedy include a complex plot, character, and proper structure and construction. The plot itself should not simply tell the series of events that occur in the story. Rather, it should focus on how the story can be presented in a way to evoke emotions from the audience, such as pity and fear. The characters in a tragedy should also not start from a spot of despair and work towards success. While a basic development from fortune to adversity would also not be ideal for a tragedy, adding more complexity to this story and including aspects that encourage fear or pity would contribute to developing an ideal tragedy. The construction of how the characters reach their final downfall is also a significant element of an ideal tragedy. For instance, not only should a character have a level of relatability to them, but they should also meet their downfall in a unfortunate and undeserving manner. Often, the story should be planned out so that the character goes into ruin despite their morals or intentions.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  "An ideal tragedy should possess a meticulously crafted plot that goes beyond simply recounting the events. It should be designed to evoke emotional responses from the audience by employing elements like pity and fear. The characters should exhibit a complex interplay of circumstances and emotions, where setbacks are a result of circumstances and not a lack of inherent worth. Their downfall should be tragic and unexpected, often orchestrated to show the injustice of fate. Additionally, the way characters reach their ultimate demise should be relatable and highlight the impact of fate and circumstance on the human condition."

column3: Aristotle believed that tragedies should follow a "complex plan", paragraph two states, "A perfect tragedy should, as we have seen, be arranged not on the simple but the complex plan"(Aristotle 2). Aristotle states here that a perfect tragedy isn't put together by an uncomplicated plan but is put together with a complex plan. Reading further into the story Aristotle also believed that a perfect tragedy should involve actions containing pity or actions of fear, in paragraph two it also states, "It should, moreover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear, this being the distinctive mark of tragic imitation" (Aristotle 2). Further, into paragraph two, it informs the readers by saying, "There remains, then, the character between these two extremes — that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error of judgment or frailty" (Aristotle 2). These three elements were what Aristotle described as an ideal tragedy.  With summarizing and reading, we as readers were able to understand and comprehend the ideas and thoughts that Aristotle had, to make his reading stronger and more entertaining for his audience
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  Aristotle believed that tragedies should be deliberately arranged with meticulous planning, as the text reveals in paragraph two. A perfect tragedy, according to Aristotle, is an intricate orchestration, not a haphazard or simple plan. His analysis extended to the psychological aspects of tragedy, emphasizing the importance of pity and fear in triggering the audience's emotions. Essentially, tragedy should resonate with the audience by showcasing characters who both possess good character and are prone to making mistakes, reflecting human experiences.

column4: The meat industry concealed spoiled meats through various methods, including canning, chopping, mixing with other meats, and applying smelly concoctions to disguise the smell. This allows the meat to be sold to customers regardless of its condition.

column4: The diverse social class involved in the government of slaves, farmers, soldiers, and artisans was remarkably complex. While farmers and slaves were considered equal in terms of their rights, the reality was that they held vastly different social standing. Ordinary citizens were expected to work hard, regardless of their class, and those who did not want to work could be forced to do so. This harsh treatment disadvantaged the poor and marginalized, who had to work under dire conditions. They were subjected to humiliation and oppression, which was particularly difficult for those with limited social mobility.

column3: Aristotle describes an element an ideal tragedy must have is the actions that create pity or fear in the reader. Without those feelings in the reader, it is not a true tragedy. Another element that a tragedy must have is that the hero of the story cannot follow the story line of moving from prosperity to adversity because it does not incite the feelings a true tragedy must have. One last element of an ideal tragedy is the author should not show the downfall of a character who is mainly shown as the villian. This downfall would satisfy the reader but it would not create the feelings which Aristotle believes is esential to a tragedy.
column4: Aristotle believed that an ideal tragedy should contain drama that evokes emotions such as pity and fear in the audience. Additionally, he considered the hero's journey to be essential for a tragedy to be considered genuine. Lastly, the author should avoid revealing the character's downfall, since such an event would diminish the emotional impact of the tragedy.

column3: As described by Aristotle, one element of an ideal tragedy is one that effectively voices it plot through a single lense from which is complex and venturing out into different perspectives instead of and rather than being clear and concise and simplistic to a certain degree. This is supported within the passage in paragraph 2 where it states, "A perfect tragedy should...be arranged not on the simple but on the complex plan." This quote by Aristotle is comprehending the purpose of the passage to build up the ideal tragedy, and to make the experience for the audience more interesting and worth-while to bring about analogies and comparison on the greatness of tragedies, in general. Another element of an ideal tragedy, according to Aristotle, is the use of pity and fear through imitation of certain actions from which  is a persuasive technique used to bring in the audience for more and feel compassion for the main character being affected at hand. Evidence from the text to support this statement is near the beginning of paragraph 2 where it states, "It should, moreover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear, this being the distinctive mark of tragic imitation." From this expression by Aristotle, we can sense the urgence of pity and fear to the makeup of a tragedy and from which, in line, feeds into the different objectives of a tragedy and what makes a tragedy ideal to Greek playwrights. Last, but not least, the third element of an ideal tragedy mentioned is to have a tragedy that is of a single reference and reasoning from which is the result of misassumed and misfortunate actions rather than of actual bad influence and illicit actions, as seen within paragraph 3 where it states, "A well-constructed plot should, therefore, be single in its issue, rather than double...[i]t should come about as the result not of vice, but of some great error or frailty."
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  An ideal tragedy, according to Aristotle, is one that explores the complexities and perspectives of its story through a multifaceted lens. A well-structured tragedy, according to Aristotle, should be complex and deviate from a simple and straightforward portrayal to offer a more nuanced and intriguing experience for the audience. This complexity should be achieved through the deliberate manipulation of the plot, which should be rich and layered. Moreover, an ideal tragedy should use its power of pity and fear to engage the audience and evoke a sense of compassion for the protagonist's suffering. Finally, a tragedy of a single reference and reasoning should be constructed on a foundation of miscalculations and misfortunes rather than on the assumption of evil or negative intention.

Finally, a true tragedy must have a neutral main character, who's misfortune or ill judgement leads to their downfall.

column3: The factory would cover up the spoiled meat in various ways. One of the ways they would cover it up was to cover up the smell with soda and chemistry things. This would hide that the meat was bad unles someone was testing the meat. The narrator says, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." (Sinclair 2). The factory would also remove the parts of the meat that were visably bad. They would cut it out and cut it a different way. The factory started making boneless hams, skinned hams, california hams, and many different cuts of meat.  Lastly,  the factory would make sausage out of all of the lefftovers. They would grind up the meat into small pieces and no one could tell what was really in them.  In conclusion, the factory had many ways to use or cover up the spolied meat.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  The factory used various techniques to conceal spoiled meat. To disguise the smell of spoiled meat, they would add chemical substances like soda and chemicals to the food. This strategy hid the smell from those testing the meat, adding a layer of secrecy to their testing process.  The factory also removed parts of the spoiled meat that were visibly bad. They cut out and organized these parts into various ways, creating diverse shapes and sizes. The factory used these methods to create unappetizing meat substitutes often sold at cafeterias, where students and workers would purchase the "free-lunch meat."  Furthermore, the factory transformed leftover scraps into sausages. They ground up these leftovers and mixed them with water or other ingredients to create meat substitute sausages. These sausages lacked the original taste and odor of the spoiled meat, providing substitutes for those looking for an edible meal during free lunch.

column3: One element of an ideal tragedy as described by Aristotle is that the tragic hero should be somewhere in between a great person and a horrible person whose downfall is a result of an error in judgement. This will be effective in creating feelings of pity and fear for the reader which are two important moods that should result from a tragedy. Another element of an ideal tragedy that Aristotle described is that the tragic hero should be someone well-known and successful. Aristotle uses the examples of Oedipus and Thyestes because both are of royal descent, helping to once again get across the feeling of fear by showing the reader that someone so fortunate may not always be so lucky. Finally, a feature that Aristotle mentioned that should be included in order to create an ideal tragedy would be that the character’s fortune should go from good to bad as opposed to it going from bad to good. This reverse in fortune would create a feeling of pity for the character as the reader would feel sorry for them as they face their downfall.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  "A tragedy, as Aristotle described, should feature a protagonist who exists somewhere between a hero and a villain. This creates a sense of pity and fear in the audience, as it evokes both awe and trepidation. Aristotle further emphasized that the protagonist should be well-known and successful. By showcasing the potential for misfortune that comes with fame and fortune, he reinforced the fear and uncertainty often experienced when dealing with such individuals. Lastly, Aristotle considered it essential to include a dynamic in the character's fortune, shifting between good fortune and bad fortune. This fluctuation in fortunes creates a sense of empathy and compassion for the protagonist as viewers can fully understand and relate to the character's struggle."

column3: The factory would use a variety of ways to cover up the spoiled meat. First, when the meat came out of pickle it would be sour so they would rub it with soda to get rid of the smell to be able to sell it. They would also perform any "miracle" of chemistry, "giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose" (Sinclair p 2). To save time and increase their capacity, they used a machine that would be able to pickle a ham in a few seconds, but would sometimes leave the hams spoiled with a disgusting odor. To solve this issue, the packers used a stronger pickle. After smoking the hams, some would be found to have gone bad but were still sold to the public as "Number Three Grade". To solve this problem, they decided to extract the bone and insert a white-hot iron, getting rid of all but Number One Grade. To be able to keep selling to the general public, the packers made up numerous schemes and "they had what they called 'boneless hams,' which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and 'California hams,' which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy 'skinned hams,' which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no  one would buy them--that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled 'head cheese!'" (Sinclair p 2). When the whole ham was spoiled, it went to another department where they would mix it with half a ton of other meat, even if the other meat was moldy and white, and then it would be dosed with borax and glycerin.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  The factory used a variety of methods to conceal spoiled meat, including making it sour, performing chemical tricks, and using an automated machine that could pickle hams quickly. To save time, they experimented with different pickles, eventually settling on one that was stronger and more effective. After they smoked the hams, some were deemed 'Number Three Grade' despite being spoiled but still sold. They removed the bone and inserted a hot iron, resulting in a final product sold under the 'Number One Grade' label. To keep the meat available and to ensure freshness, the factory employed various strategies, including mixing spoiled meat with other scraps and applying a special mixture to brighten the color.

column3: He says, "A perfect tragedy should, as we have seen, be arranged not on the simple but on the complex plan." This means that there is so much to a perfect tragedy that it is near impossible to have a perfect tragedy. "It follows plainly, in the first place, that the change of fortune presented must not be the spectacle of a virtuous man brought from prosperity to adversity: for this moves meither pity nor fear; it merely shocks us." This is explaining what a perfect tragedy would consist of. "Nor again, that of a bad man passing from adversity to prosperity: for nothing can be more alien to the spirit of Tragedy; it possesses no single tragic quality; it neither satisfies the moral sense nor calls forth pity or fear." This is explaining how not everything tragic is predictable.
column4: "    He argues that a perfect tragedy is multifaceted, demanding a nuanced approach rather than a straightforward or clichéd approach. He emphasizes that a tragedy that hinges solely on the spectacle of a virtuous character transitioning from prosperity to adversity would lack emotional impact. Similarly, a tragedy that relies solely on the transformation of a bad person from adversity to prosperity would be alien to the tragic spirit. He cautions that a tragedy should not be predictable, presenting a unique and complex narrative that defies easy categorization.

column4: Sure. Here is the rewritten passage:  "They mixed spoiled meat with pickles, then rubbed the meat with soda, making it smell less. They replaced the bone of ham with a hollow iron, then filled it with pickle. If the meat still smelled bad, they poured more pickle in, if it still smelled bad, they pumped it with a stronger pickle. If the meat was spoiled and moldy, they transformed it into sausage, and if it was white and moldy after being cleaned, they coated it with chemicals to remove the mold and then returned it to the hoppers to eat. column3: Ra was the sun god of ancient Egyptian myth and religion, and was often worshipped as the Creator god. Osiris was the god of resurrection and the dead, as well as ruler of the underworld. Isis, the sister and wife of Osiris, was the goddess of women, fertility, motherhood, and children, as well as protector of the dead.
column4: Ra was the primordial god of creation in ancient Egyptian mythology. Osiris was the god of the afterlife, and the ruler of the underworld. Isis, the goddess of women, was also the wife of Osiris and the goddess of all things that sustain life.

column3: The meat packing industries of America found numerous ways to cover up the fact that they would sell spoiled meat.  In paragraph two it states, "Jonas told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smel.." it also states later in that same paragraph, "...by  plugnign this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds.  And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spolied, some of them with an ordor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them." Later in life there was a new method, they would take out the bone and replace it with a white-hot iron. Over time the pacheres organized, what were called, "schemes." One scheme was called the "boneless ham. " Paragraph two states, "...what they called "boneless hams," which they were all the odds and ends of posk stuffed into casings." Many more awful schemes were made. Some involved the whole ham being spoiled and others involved awful parts of the pig to be cased as a stomach-disasting mixture. When sausage was made and it came back from Europe rejected and moldy white, companies covered the sausage in borax and glycerin before being made all over again from humans.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  "The meat packing industry in America used deceptive practices to cover up the fact that they were selling spoiled meat.  Paragraph two mentions that they would often sell sour meat that had been taken out of pickle, rubbing it up with soda to take away the smell. Additionally, the passage describes a method where a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds by plugging a needle into the meat and working with his foot. Furthermore, despite these deceptive practices, there were instances of spoiled hams found that were so bad that they could be almost unbearable to be around.  Later, the meat packing industry used more unethical practices.  They would sometimes take out the bone from the meat and replace it with a white-hot iron to fill it completely.  The meat packing industry organized schemes, such as the "boneless ham" scheme, where they would stuff their leftover meat into casings to make a profit. Many of these schemes involved the whole ham being spoiled or the inclusion of meat from other animals, making the final product inedible."

column3: The factories used various methods to cover up the spoiled meat.  One way they would do this is they would "rub it with soda to cover up the smell." Another method they commonly used was to dose old, moldy sausage with borax  and glycerin. They would then dump it into hoppers so that it could be made over for home consumption. (paragraph 3)
column4: The factories employed multiple disguises to conceal the spoiled meat. One strategy involved coating the meat in soda to mask its unpleasant smell. Another tactic involved injecting old, moldy sausage chunks with borax and glycerin, which were then diluted and poured into hoppers to alter their texture and appearance

column3: "After only three days, the experiment took on a life of its own" this shows that the Third Wave was developed over a short period of time. The reasoning for this is because students from all over thr school were joining in. There was drastic improvment and in the students acedmic skills and tremendous motivation. it continued to grow over the week with more than 200 participants. They students were  more involved in the project and their disciplone and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that jones felt that it was getting out of coontrol. He lied to the students that the experiment was a nationwide movement . This led to the end of the experiment when they students were presented witht eh black channel, and Jones annonced they had been apart of a demonstartion of how willingly it is to creat superiorty, also how it can lead to horriable things in the name of the states's honor.
column4: After only three days, the experiment spiraled out of control, demonstrating the sheer dynamism and rapid development of the Third Wave. It was a collaborative effort involving students from various corners of the school. The intensity and quality of their contributions soared, ultimately showcasing their academic brilliance and the boundless dedication of each participant. However, Jones's deception, signaling a nationwide movement, ultimately led to the termination of the experiment, leaving the students presented with the unsettling black channel. Jones revealed that they were part of a hidden demonstration aimed at showcasing the power of creating superiorty for the sake of the state's honor, revealing that it could lead to harmful consequences.

column3: An ideal tragedy should include a change of fortune from good to bad. This means will be a good person who make a terrible mistake, which makes it a tragedy. Another ideal tragedy could be a double thread of plot. This means that in a movie there might be two bad guys who are enemies. You would think that something bad will happen, but in the end they turn out friends.
column4: An ideal tragedy involves a shift from good to bad fortune, presenting a protagonist who makes an appalling error that results in a tragic outcome. Alternatively, a double thread of plot presents a storyline where two antagonists are adversaries, creating anticipation of a bad outcome but ultimately leading to a positive resolution.

column3: The three elements of an ideal tragedy should involve a complex plan, awaken feelings of pity and fear, and should center around a man who is not good nor evil, but whose misfortune is brought about by a mistake. Aristotle says all of these elements in paragraph two: "A perfect tragedy should, as we have seen, be arranged not on the simple but on the complex plan. It should, moreover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear, this being the distinctive mark of tragic imitation." and "here remains, then, the character between these two extremes — that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error of judgment or frailty.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  "An ideal tragedy entails a multifaceted approach to storytelling, fostering a sense of pity and trepidation in the audience. It is centered around a protagonist whose flaws and mistakes unintentionally contribute to the tragic outcome. Aristotle's definition emphasizes the importance of symmetrical composition, mirroring those actions that elicit both sympathy and terror in the audience. His characterization exemplifies this dichotomy."

column3: Ancient Eygpt's  social structure was like a pyramid. At the top, there were pharaohs. Pharhaohs were thoughtbof like gods. Heir subjects believed that they could controll the Nile, famines, and death. Of course, the pharaohs had viziers which supervized and made sure that taxes were collected. Below the pharaohs were nobles and priests. Nobles held government posts and priests pleased the pharohs. Next were  soldiers. Soldiers supervized those below them and fought in wars. Along with soldiers, skilled workers sold needed materials such as pottery and papyrus. At the very bottom of this pyramid are the slaves. They were forced to work on buildings and worship the pharaohs. There were also farmers who grew crops, raised animals, and made sure the water sytems were in good shape. They also payed taxes which resulted in a lot of hay. It is also possible to get a good education and work your way up. Meaning, you don't have to stay a farmer forever.
column4: In simpler terms, the ancient Egyptian social structure was hierarchical, with pharaohs at the apex, followed by nobles, priests, soldiers, skilled workers, slaves, and farmers.

column3: One of the ways that the factories would cover up spoiled meat was by covering it in many chemicals in order to block the odor. According to the article, it states that  " also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose."  Another way that the spoiled meat was covered up  was by mixing it up with other meats to remove the odor. According to the article, it states that "... and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. "
column4: Even though they employed various chemical concoctions to obscure the smell of spoiled meat, the article emphasizes the astonishing feats of chemistry demonstrated by these experts. Their ability to transform any type of meat, fresh or aged, whole or chopped, regardless of color and flavor, eradicated any scent. In addition, they skillfully mixed spoiled meat with other meats to dispel its odor. Their creations demonstrate the boundless creativity of nature and the remarkable ability of science to solve problems.
